results.title: Directing a play
results.creator_credit: Betty Edmonds, Robert Edmonds and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description: Rehearsals of Louise Dale Spoor’s adaptation of Mark Twain’s “Tom Sawyer” are used to illustrate the work of the director in the performance of a stage play. Shows the first reading of the play by cast and director followed by a discussion of the play, its actions and characters; preliminary work on the stage floor, rehearsals without props; recording of action times and stage movements; the first dress rehearsal.

results.title: Directing a film: Ionesco's 'The New tenant'
results.creator_credit: Larry Yust and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: To better acquaint students with the role of the director in motion picture production, this film takes them behind the scenes both before and during the filming of Eugene Ionesco’s play “The New Tenant”. Scenes from the early stages of planning and preparation are intercut with scenes from the completed film version of the play to enable students to better understand how the director’s initial thoughts and ideas are realized.

results.title: Dipping sheep
results.brief_description: Stresses the importance, at dipping time, of making a clean muster and dipping all sheep on the property. The importance of keeping sheep in the bath for a sufficient length of time and the necessity of following the manufacturer’s instructions when mixing the dip are also stressed. Various types of spray plants and plunge dips are shown.

results.title: Diplomacy
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The history of the diplomat’s functions and skills. The commentary includes quotations from figures as contrasted as Demosthenes, Machiavelli, and President Kennedy. Shows how the modern career diplomat exercises techniques developed over centuries, but today is supported by the resources of modern technology. He must have qualities of patience, integrity and a strong sense of national purpose. Narrated by Alastair Duncan.

results.title: The Dinosaur age
results.creator_credit: Paul Burnford and Film Associates of California
results.brief_description: Describes the work of two palaeontologists looking for fossils on a rocky hillside. They uncover the paddle or flipper of a plesiosaur which was a large water living reptile or sea serpent closely related to dinosaurs. The methods used to uncover the bones, preserve them, and transport them to a museum are shown, also the tedious work of assembling the bones, fitting them in position and reconstructing the entire animals are explained. Models of representative animals of the age of dinosaurs are shown.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Burnford and Film Associates of California

results.title: Dimensions
results.creator_credit: Bernard Longpre, Jacques Bobet and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film without words (with titles in French) in which simple actions achieve surprising results. A man wants a door in a wall; he draws a rectangle and, presto, there is an opening. In the same way, he conjures up furnishings. If too high or too low, a raising or lowering of a finger puts everything right. The film is a sort of lesson in proportions, which young viewers especially should enjoy. Cast: Paul Buissonneau, Louise Latraverse.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bernard Longpre, Jacques Bobet and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Dikes
results.creator_credit: Roger Blais and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A dramatized presentation of the work of the Maritime Marshlands Reclamation Administration in the reclaiming of flooded agricultural regions along the Bay of Fundy. Through the account of a dike-keeper, the film describes the destruction that follows the breaking of long-neglected dikes during autumn rains and shows how M.M.R.A. engineers are cooperating with New Brunswick land-owners in the big task of keeping at bay the inundations of the sea.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roger Blais and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Dihedral kaleidoscopes (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Art Landy, International Film Bureau and University of Minnesota
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Presents basic ideas of symmetry by exhibiting dihedral groups by reflections of intersecting mirrors. From reflection in a single mirror the film proceeds to study the surprising effects and beautiful patterns that can be produced with two or three mirrors. Observations on the general case are made as well as on the limiting case in which two mirrors are parallel.

results.title: The Digestive system
results.creator_credit: William Kay and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Animation, x-ray photography, and laboratory experiments show how the human digestive system breaks food down into substances which will provide energy for living. Examines the behaviour and function of each organ or structure involved in the digestive process.
results.description: Animation, x-ray photography, and laboratory experiments show how the human digestive system breaks food down into substances which will provide energy for living. Examines the behaviour and function of each organ or structure involved in the digestive process.

results.title: Digestion of food
results.brief_description: A summary of the digestive process, including the following aspects: the function of the mouth; stomach, and small intestine; secretions and enzymes - the systems affected and the products formed; reactions, digestive movements, and their control (recorded by microphotography); the relation of the circulatory and nervous systems to the digestive process; motility of the digestive tract - normal movements, hypermotility, inhibition, hunger contractions, segmentations, peristalsis and anti-peristalsis; and motility of the intestinal villi.
